trial_identification.studytitle: Effects of pelvic floor muscle training in pregnant women
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Effects of pelvic floor muscle training on pelvic floor muscle function in women during their first pregnancies measured by perineometer.

interventions.interventions: pelvic floor muscle training in healthy pregnant women in four different positions during 16 weeks/sessions (the sessions duration was 30 minutes, once a week), beginning at 20 th week of gestation, one-on-one training with a physiotherapist to analyze the effect during the pregnancyand post partum. Pelvic floor muscle training is a training for the pelvic floor muscle to improve the strength and the function of these muscles thet support the abdominal organs and realize the continence (fecal and urinary)
interventions.comparator: the same number of healthy pregnant women who do not practice the pelvic floor training during this period

primaryOutcome.outcome: pelvic floor muscle function of evaluated by perineometry and digital palpation
pelvic floor muscle function during pregnancy and after delivery
primaryOutcome.timepoint: 24th and 36th week of pregnancy and 6 weeks after delivery

secondaryOutcome.outcome: self-related-incontinence asking if she lose urine in the last month by interview with participant
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: 36th week of pregnancy and 6 weeks after delivery

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: woman in the first pregnancy, without complications and who can contract correctly the pelvic floor
